thread.title: The Fyfe move that gives Freo great hope
thread.title_full: The Fyfe move that gives Freo great hope

title: The Fyfe move that gives Freo great hope
text:
Eagles won't turn back on Ben 0:30 Nat Fyfe to deal with Fremantle first on new contract, rival AFL clubs told not to make offers at this stage February 27, 2017 5:24pm @jakeniallfox Source: FOX SPORTS FREMANTLE superstar free agent Nat Fyfe is not yet fielding offers from rival clubs, with the Dockers given the first opportunity to secure their champion on a long-term deal. 
While there has been speculation about the kind of money the new Fremantle skipper would attract in his free agency season — certain to exceed $1 million per season — Fyfe and his management have decided to deal first with Fremantle before even considering testing the market. 
A number of clubs have approached Fyfe’s management, but they have been told not to make offers at this stage. 
With the Dockers given first crack at signing the 2015 Brownlow Medallist, it appears his services are Fremantle’s to lose. His management have not ruled out fielding offers from rival clubs, but the ball, at least initially, is in Fremantle’s court. 
But it is understood Fyfe’s decision on his future will not rest on money, given that he would command a massive contract of several million dollars, regardless of where he played in 2018. 
The decision will be more about the prospects of on-field success in the future, with Fyfe having already sought information about Fremantle’s list management plans for the future. Nat Fyfe was one of Fremantle’s best players against West Coast in the JLT Community Series. Source: Getty Images 
Fyfe, 25, is looking at signing a long-term deal, in what is expected to be the most significant contract of his career — and among the heftiest in the AFL. 
Fyfe last year said he could test the free agency market — a stance that his coach Ross Lyon has endorsed. 
When announced as captain, Fyfe said he saw his future at Fremantle. 
“The contract stuff will take care of itself, but I have said publicly and nothing has changed that I want to play my football at Fremantle,” he said. 
In a subsequent interview, he suggested he could sign a deal if “I feel at any point it (contract speculation) is affecting me or, more importantly, the team and the club”. 
“I’ll look to do something pretty quickly,’’ he told SEN. 
Fyfe has recovered well from the broken fibula that ended his 2016 season — his second break to the left leg — and performed well in Fremantle’s JLT Community Series loss to West Coast in Wonthella.
